newsitem.title: TUNISIA: Arafat urges Arabs to oppose Israel on settlements.
newsitem.headline: Arafat urges Arabs to oppose Israel on settlements.

text.p: Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on Friday called on Arab and Moslem countries to take steps to force Israel to stop building Jewish settlements in and around Arab East Jerusalem.
Arafat's spokesman Marwan Kanafani dismissed reports that the Palestinian leader had made a new pledge to stop violence when he met U.S. envoy Dennis Ross in Rabat on Thursday.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Friday said after meeting with Ross that Arafat had assured the envoy that "terrorism" would stop.

"The president didn't charge Ross with a new position regarding violence because the president's and Palestinian Authority's stand is clear on this issue and does not require to be reaffirmed," Kanafani told Reuters in a comment on Netanyahu report.
Kanafani was speaking at Tunis airport before Arafat boarded an EgyptAir flight for Cairo on his way back to Gaza.
Earlier on Friday, Arafat told reporters after briefing Tunisian President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali on the crisis in the Middle East peace process:
"These things...call for a quick Palestinian, Arab and Moslem move to face these dangerous developments not only against Jerusalem but also against the palestinian people."
Arafat said such moves would be based on previous decisions at Moslem and Arab summit meetings.
Resolutions adopted in Islamabad and Cairo last year threatened to freeze diplomatic ties established by some Arab and Moslem states with Israel.
Arafat accused Israel of aiming, through Jewish settlements, to cut Arab East Jerusalem off from Palestinian territories in the West Bank.
"I told President Ben Ali that despite these difficulties, we will pray together in Jerusalem, capital of the Palestinian state," he added.
